column1: [[Image:Ted Nasmith - The Oath of Fëanor.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Ted Nasmith]] - ''The Oath of Fëanor'']]The dreadful irrevocable oath taken by [[Fëanor]] and [[Sons of Fëanor|his seven sons]] in the city of [[Tirion]]. They swore in the name of [[Ilúvatar]] that they would not rest until the three [[Silmarils]] were in their hands
column2: and to make war on any who withheld them.  Tolkien remarked that it was an oath which should never have been taken
column3: reflecting on the Biblical passage concerning such oaths.

column1: At the time the Oath was sworn
column2: [[Morgoth]] held all three of the Silmarils
column3: having stolen them from Fëanor's stronghold at [[Formenos]]. Driven by the unbreakable Oath
column4: Fëanor led the greater part of the [[Noldor]] out of [[Aman]] and back to [[Middle-earth]]
column5: in hopeless pursuit of the [[Dark Lord]]. Fëanor himself was mortally wounded by [[Balrogs]] in the Noldor's first assault. From that time on
column6: while Morgoth held the three Silmarils in his [[Iron Crown]]
column7: the [[Elves of Beleriand]] were bound by a common enemy.

column1: The true danger of the Oath was revealed after [[Beren]] and [[Lúthien]] recovered one of the three Silmarils from the depths of [[Angband]]. Thereupon
column2: the Sons of Fëanor made war upon the other Elves of Beleriand for the recovery of the Jewel. They attacked and destroyed the kingdom of [[Doriath]]
column3: killing [[Thingol]]'s Heir [[Dior]]. When the Silmaril escaped them there
column4: they discovered that it was held at the [[Mouths of Sirion]] by Dior's daughter [[Elwing]]; again they attacked
column5: and again the Silmaril escaped them. Carried out to sea by the power of [[Ulmo]]
column6: Elwing brought it to her husband [[Eärendil]]
column7: and they sailed with it back into the West.

column1: That Silmaril was lost to Fëanor's sons
column2: but two more remained on Morgoth's Crown. After the [[War of Wrath]] and Morgoth's defeat at the end of the [[First Age]]
column3: just two of the original oath-takers survived
column4: Fëanor's eldest sons [[Maedhros]] and [[Maglor]]. The former put forth a plan that the latter reluctantly accepted.  They stole the Silmarils from the camp of the victorious host
column5: but because of the evils they had committed in recovering them
column6: they found that they could no longer touch the holy Jewels without enduring searing pain. In despair
column7: Maedhros threw himself and his Silmaril into the depths of the Earth
column8: while Maglor cast his into the deep ocean. Maglor was the last of the oath-takers
column9: and was said to wander the shores of the world lamenting his pain and loss.

column1: The Oath itself is as follows:<ref>{{MR|P2m}}

Be he foe or friend, be he foul or clean,
brood of Morgoth or bright Vala,
Elda or Maia or Aftercomer,
Man yet unborn upon Middle-earth,
neither law, nor love, nor league of swords,
dread nor danger, not Doom itself,
shall defend him from Fëanor, and Fëanor's kin,
whoso hideth or hoardeth, or in hand taketh,
finding keepeth or afar casteth
a Silmaril. This swear we all:
death we will deal him ere Day's ending,
woe unto world's end! Our word hear thou,
Eru Allfather! To the everlasting
Darkness doom us if our deed faileth.
On the holy mountain hear in witness
and our vow remember, Manwë and Varda!
